channel.title: DutchNews.nl
channel.description: DutchNews.nl brings daily news from The Netherlands in English

item.title: More Dutch golds in skating mass start, taking medal total to 20
item.description:
More Dutch golds in skating mass start, taking medal total to 20

February 21, 2026

Marijke Groenewoud and Jorrit Bergsma have added two more gold medals to the Dutch Winter Olympic collection, each taking the top spot in the mass start race.

The gold is 27-year-old Groenewoud’s first individual medal, having won silver in the team pursuit earlier in the Games. She follows Irene Schouten, who won mass start gold at the Beijing Olympics four years ago. Ivanie Blondin of Canada and Mia Manganello took silver and bronze.

In the men’s race, Jorrit Bergsma won gold ahead of Viktor Thorup of Denmark and Andrea Giovannini of Italy, who edged out favourite Jordan Stolz. It is the 40-year-old’s second medal of the Games after he won a surprise bronze in the 10,000 metres.

The Dutch squad has won 20 medals at the Games, including 10 gold, which is a record. The Netherlands is now in third place in the medals table, just ahead of Italy, with one day of competition to go.

Five of the Dutch golds were for long-track speed skating events and five for short-track.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pascoe

item.title: Dutch men win short track relay gold, sealing Olympic success
item.description:
Dutch men win short track relay gold, sealing Olympic success

February 21, 2026

The Dutch men’s short track team have won Olympic gold in the relay after years of near misses, delivering the team medal coach Niels Kerstholt had set his heart on.

Jens van ’t Wout, Melle van ’t Wout, Friso Emons and Teun Boer skated the final, with Itzhak de Laat as reserve.

The title completed an already remarkable tournament for the short track team. Jens van ’t Wout finished with three gold medals and one bronze, while his brother Melle van ’t Wout added individual silver. Xandra Velzeboer won two gold medals in the women’s events.

Kerstholt said he wanted his skaters to show what they stand for. “We wanted to show who we are and what a great sport this is. A team medal is part of that – and this one is gold,” he said.

The win also carried personal weight. Kerstholt was part of the relay squad in 2014 that fell in the Olympic final and missed out on a medal. “Finally, revenge for 2014,” he said.

Disappointment

There was disappointment for Velzeboer in the women’s 1,500 metres, however. Both she and former Olympic champion Suzanne Schulting fell in the semi-finals, putting them out of medal contention.

Olympic skating concludes on Saturday with the mass start races. Jorrit Bergsma and Stijn van de Bunt are in action in the men’s semi-finals with Marijke Groenewoud and Bente Kerkhoff in the women’s event.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pascoe

item.title: Gold for Antoinette Rijpma-de Jong in the 1,500m speed skating
item.description:
Gold for Antoinette Rijpma-de Jong in the 1,500m speed skating

February 20, 2026

Antoinette Rijpma-de Jong has delivered the Netherlands’ latest Olympic medal – gold in the women’s 1,500 metres.

Rijpma-de Jong won bronze in the same event four years ago.

Ragne Wiklund of Norway took the silver and Valérie Maltais of Canada the bronze. Femke Kok, who earlier won gold in the 500 metres and silver in the 1,000 metres was fifth.

The Netherlands is currently fourth in the medals table, with seven gold, seven silver and three bronze, with more potential medals to come.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pascoe

item.title: Man arrested at Eindhoven airport with €250,000 in cash
item.description:
Man arrested at Eindhoven airport with €250,000 in cash

February 20, 2026

Border police at Eindhoven airport have picked up a 54-year-old man from Deventer who was carrying €250,000 in cash.

The money was in the man’s luggage and was spotted during a check on his belongings. The cash – €50 and €100 notes – was hidden in envelopes and in articles of clothing, the border police said.

The man failed to provide a proper reason why he was carrying so much cash and was arrested on suspicion of money laundering. The cash has been confiscated.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pascoe

item.title: Caroline van der Plas steps down as leader of pro-farmer BBB
item.description:
Caroline van der Plas steps down as leader of pro-farmer BBB

February 20, 2026

Caroline van der Plas is stepping down as leader of the pro-countryside party BBB that she co-founded in 2019.

Henk Vermeer, party co-founder and Van der Plas’ right hand man, will take over as party chief. He has been an MP since 2023.

The BBB grew out of the farmers’ protests, propelling Van der Plas into the spotlights. The party won one seat in parliament in 2021 but emerged as the big winner in the 2023 provincial elections and the senate vote.

The BBB went on to win seven seats in the 2023 general election and became part of the coalition government, along with the far right PVV, the VVD and conservative NSC.

Since then, however, support for the BBB has plunged and is has just four seats in the current parliament.

Van der Plas will remain and MP and said that by stepping away from the leadership she will be able to represent the interests of the countryside more forcefully. “I have led the party for five years and it is time for the party to move into the next phase,” she said in a statement.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pascoe

item.title: New government’s plans will reduce spending power: CPB
item.description:
New government’s plans will reduce spending power: CPB

February 20, 2026

Most people will have a little less to spend as a result of the new government’s policies but low income households will be hardest hit, according to calculations by the government’s macro-economic forecasting agency CPB.

The new administration, a minority coalition of the VVD, D66 and CDA, will formally take office next week.

Teachers and people in the armed forces in particular will have more to spend in the coming years, the CPB said in its analysis of the plans. The new government will also make some advances in terms with dealing with climate change and nitrogen-based pollution but not enough to meet targets, the CPB said.

The impact of its housing plans on the shortage of housing will also be “slight”.

In particular, the decision to increase the healthcare own risk element to €460 will disproportionately hit low income households, the CPB said. They will also be hit by the decision to merge two child-related benefits. On average, spending power will go down by 0.4%.

The Netherlands is expected to hit the new Nato norm of spending 5% of GDP on defence and defence-related infrastucture, the analysis shows. More money has also been allocated to education.

The agency points out that because the coalition does not have a majority in either house of parliament, its plans may not go ahead in their current form anyway.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pascoe

item.title: Podcast: The Half-Baked Diplomas and Fake Fish Tarts Edition
item.description:
Podcast: The Half-Baked Diplomas and Fake Fish Tarts Edition

February 20, 2026

Want to support the DutchNews podcast and keep up our stocks of stroopwafels and orange tompouces? Click here to become a Patreon backer

Rob Jetten starts his term one finance minister short of a full cabinet after Natalie van Berkel is found to have inflated her credentials on LinkedIn. More new homes are being built, but not enough to tackle the housing shortage or cool the property market. The armed forces are struggling to recruit chefs, mechanics and other support staff in the battle to spend the extra Nato billions. A new rail link is planned to connect Eindhoven to Brussels. And the Dutch shorttrack skaters eclipse the stars of the big oval at the Winter Olympics.

Dutch News · The Half-Baked Diplomas and Fake Fish Tarts Edition – Week 8 – 2026

Ophef of the week: Fines for Carnaval floats spoil the party in Helmond

Hot tip leads to cannabis plantation in motorway bridge support

D66 agriculture minister pranked TV chefs as schoolboy with fish pie

News

D66 candidate for finance ministry pays price for misleading LinkedIn profile

Dummies’ guide to the main parties in local elections

Political parties start waking up to the power of the expat vote

More houses built in Q4 2025 but still well short of government target

Many households are living in homes that are too big for them

Blaricum has most expensive homes in Netherlands, Kerkrade the cheapest

Defence ministry turns to recruitment agencies to tackle personnel shortfall

Support for Maga ideas grows but Dutch reject US interference

New Eindhoven to Brussels train line aims to boost cross-border ties

Sport

Van ’t Wout brothers add shorttrack silver and bronze to Dutch medal hall

Shorttrack star Xandra Velzeboer bags second Olympic gold at 1000m

Femke Kok takes gold in 500m, Leerdam second in reversal of 1000m

Silver for Dutch women in skating team pursuit as China prove too strong

Dutch bow out of T20 World Cup with valiant 17-run loss to hosts India

Chess grandmaster Jan Timman, “best of the West”, dies aged 74
item.dc:creator: Gordon Darroch

item.title: “Nice pictures” turn out to be collection of Rembrandt etchings
item.description:
“Nice pictures” turn out to be collection of Rembrandt etchings

February 20, 2026

A woman from Zutphen in Gelderland who inherited a collection of “nice pictures” turns out to be the owner of 35 small etchings by Rembrandt, local broadcaster Omroep Gelderland reported.

Charlotte Meyer’s grandfather collected the etchings between 1900 and 1920. “No one was interested in etchings in those days,” she told the broadcaster. “He got 35 of them for a couple of guilders. My grandmother didn’t care much for them. They were kept but no one expected much from them.”

When she inherited the folder containing the etchings, Meyer left them in a drawer for years. During the coronavirus crisis, she studied them a bit closer and started to think that the tiny etchings were more than just pretty pictures.

When she contacted experts from the Rembrandthuis, they were “very kind but you could tell they thought, ‘there’s another one who thinks they’ve got a Rembrandt’,” she said.

But a visit to her home quickly changed their minds, Meyer said. “They were blown away. ‘Charlotte, you don’t know what you’ve got here’, they said. And I thought ‘wow, I bet they are worth a bit’”.

According to the experts, the etchings show themes that were important to him at the time, including his younger years, ups-and-downs in his career, mourning for the loss of his family and his life in poverty.

Meyer, who did not say how much the collection was valued at, said the money didn’t really interest her. Since her discovery, she has bought more etchings by Rembrandt and his contemporaries. “I have been buying works from across Europe. It’s a tricky business because there are lots of good fakes around. But I’m not falling for them, just like my granddad,” she said.

The etchings, now 70 in total,  will be on show at the Stedelijk Museum in Zutphen from March 21 to June 14.
item.dc:creator: Hanneke Sanou

item.title: Police ask for help in case of poisoned gin that killed couple
item.description:
Police ask for help in case of poisoned gin that killed couple

February 20, 2026

Police in Hilversum are asking for information following the death in 2023 of an elderly couple killed by drinking amphetamine oil hidden in a gin bottle.

A total of 4 bottles containing the drug had been sent to Seville in Spain but were not collected, police said. They were then sent back to a wine seller in the Netherlands whose address was used as a cover-up. He then put the bottles in his shop, unaware they had been tampered with.

In April 2023, the 84-year-old woman became unwell after drinking the oil and died later in hospital. Her husband, whose age was not given, showed the same symptoms and died two weeks earlier. The bottle was given to the couple as a present.

Amphetamine oil is a type of speed. The drug is usually sold as pills or powder but is also traded semi-finished.

There are no indications that more bottles ended up with clients of the store, police said.

It is not the first time bottles filled with drugs end up killing unwitting people. In 2022, a guest at a restaurant in Germany died after drinking from a champagne bottle containing mdma. That ended in the arrest of a Dutch national whose trial is currently underway.

Police are focusing on the two people who tried to pick up the package in Seville but have so far failed to trace them. The case will be featured on crime show Opsporing Verzocht next week in an effort to gain more information.
item.dc:creator: Hanneke Sanou

item.title: Driver of waste lorry “had 27 seconds” to prevent fatal accident
item.description:
Driver of waste lorry “had 27 seconds” to prevent fatal accident

February 20, 2026

The public prosecutor has demanded a community service order of 240 hours and a one-year driving license suspension for a waste lorry driver on trial for running over and killing American tourist Cindy Charles (69) in Amsterdam in 2024.

According to a police investigation, the man had 27 seconds in which he could have seen her and taken action to prevent the accident.

The driver also went against traffic for which he had permission but only when faced with an emergency which, the OM said, was not the case.

“This was not a moment of distraction. He could and should have seen her. Operating a heavy vehicle demands extra caution,” the prosecutor said.

Charles’s husband Ricky Fishman, who travelled from California to be present at the trial, addressed the court saying “strict and simple rules should be in place where trucks should come to a complete halt before turning left or right”.

He also said he forgave the driver. “It was an accident and to live with that is punishment in itself,” Fishman said.

The verdict is expected on March 5.
item.dc:creator: Hanneke Sanou
